★★★★☆

Deep Impact is the thinking person’s disaster movie: a surprisingly somber, deeply human end-of-the-world story that dares to care more about grief, sacrifice, and quiet heroism than explosions (even when it has plenty of those).

Released the same summer as Armageddon, this one actually treats the apocalypse like adults. The comet isn’t just a rock; it’s a countdown clock ticking over ordinary people making impossible choices. Téa Leoni’s journalist wrestling with her estranged parents while breaking the biggest story in history, Robert Duvall leading the Messiah crew on a suicide mission with nothing but grace and gallows humor, Elijah Wood getting married at 17 because tomorrow isn’t promised; every subplot lands because the characters feel real, not caricatures.

Morgan Freeman’s President Beck is still one of the most reassuring fictional leaders ever put on screen (that voice could calm a hurricane), and the final act doesn’t cheat: when the smaller comet hits and that East-Coast tsunami sequence rolls in with zero music, just the roar of water and James Horner’s heartbreaking choir, it’s legitimately terrifying. The last twenty minutes are pure, unashamed tearjerker territory: the astronaut farewells, the baby named after a doomed hero, the father carrying his daughter one last time… grab tissues.

It loses half a star only because some of the younger-cast drama feels a bit after-school-special at times, and the CGI tidal wave hasn’t aged perfectly.

Four stars: one for the cast giving Oscar-worthy work in a "disaster" movie, one for never insulting your intelligence, one for the emotional devastation that still wrecks me every rewatch, and one because in a genre full of Michael Bay noise, this one whispers "We love you, goodbye" and means it.

Underrated 90s classic.  
8/10. The sky really is falling… and somehow it still makes you feel less alone when it does. ☄️🌊❤️

Despite growing up in the 90s, I was completely unaware of this movie.  It was amazing! and honestly, refreshing to see an extinction-level event related to a comet, as opposed to the typical bad guy/world war.

This movie made me nostalgic as well for the good 'ol 90s.  Happy this movie randomly came into my sight, it was great!
Another disasterous disaster movie - yet not as ridiculously pathetic as Armageddon.

Filme fraco, o roteiro é fraco, as cenas são fracas, a história é fraca, o elenco é fraco, e ninguém ajuda a melhorar o filme, os personagens são fracos, e o filme deveria ter cenas bem melhores e relevantes, para fazer o filme ser bom

It's world destruction - but somehow, missions, missiles and mineshafts are kinda thrown together (mostly to fail).  The film couldn't pull off the kind of epic it wanted to be - even with Freeman.  And Leoni sucked as soon as she sat behind the news desk.

Still one of my favourte disaster films, after a rewatch. Balances human emotion with natural cataclysm brilliantly. This lens made the film that much more suspenseful and compelling.  Tea Leoni is superb as the anchor.
Melodramatic drivel.

While certainly less absurd than its "twin film" Armageddon, there still isn't much more to like in this rather contrived excuse for special effects. The production design—from the spaceships to the costumes to James Horner's commendable score—does earn some points for being better pretty much across the board though.

Groudbreaking digital effects for 1998 and still fascinates me to this day "How on Earth did they do it"? Good plot with a healthy amount of character building. Shines a light on the human insight to such a "What if" situation. It may drag on a little for some.

It’s scientifically more accurate than Armageddon, but that’s it’s only strong point.

The characters are bland and shallow, with very little intrigue or depth whatsoever. The script really moves like a textbook….instead of entertaining you and telling you a story, the bulk of the time is spent educating and convincing you why each part of the movie is practical.
The bittersweet grand finale makes up for the movie’s corny tone and sluggish pacing.
Uns dos melhores filmes dos anos 90

Please if there's excess cash in the coffers do something worthwhile instead of soaking up valuable time and resources on what really could have been shot on an android by stoners.
Misses every mark possible. Really quite pathetic.
The characters are ok I guess and the story is nice, but the movie tries to be so sophisticated and no one comes to watch a so sophisticated movie.
My favorite apocalyptic movie of all time! Easy to follow story supported by a great cast.
Better than Armageddon, just not as flashy. Also, why didn't anyone follow up on the scientist's, who died at the beginning, work?

Apocalyptic event dramatised and americanised to a level you just have to watch, and rewatch! Lol. It has a great cast, is an easy story to be able to run with and bring drama to, and has entertainment value at a level that makes rewatching it a pleasure
Although its scientific understanding is... puzzling Deep Impact is, at times, a highly entertaining watch thanks to a spot-on performance from Elijah Wood and emotionally stirring relationships.

Three things I would say about this movie. 
1. Unrealistic 
2. Terrible plot
3. Bad acting
